name: Slate
text: RT @mjs_DC: RBG had faith in humankind’s ability to better itself, to shed irrational bigotries, to come together in the pursuit of the greater good. She believed our current period of history will be remembered as an “anomaly.” It is now up to us to prove her right. https://t.co/oDsaNIUvFU

name: Slate
text: RT @lowenliu: In the days before her death, the justice dictated a statement to her granddaughter, Clara Spera: “My most fervent wish is that i I will not be replaced until a new president is installed.” https://t.co/CwG7PWuoPq via @slate

name: Slate
text: RT @LeonKrauze: Lean esto que ha escrito @mjs_DC sobre Ginsburg https://t.co/9MgWuRHPM5

name: Slate
text: RT @abbjmc: “No matter what happens, Ginsburg should not be remembered primarily for setting off the political equivalent of an atomic bomb less than two months before an election. She deserves to be exalted as the visionary that she was.” https://t.co/484Knsx8VT

name: Slate
text: Ginsburg always knew a right to equal citizenship existed. She simply had to help the Supreme Court’s male justices see it. https://t.co/tzOY17SsQw

name: Slate
text:
RT @mjs_DC: Ruth Bader Ginsburg led a revolution. It is impossible to overstate her impact on the nation. She changed the world. 

Her legacy will survive the ages. But her life's work of equal citizenship for all is now in immediate jeopardy. https://t.co/FOeGV98ax1 @Slate

name: Slate
text: Just before she died, RBG knew what the fight ahead would be. https://t.co/bZOBJbc4Yo

name: Slate
text: RT @chaubtu: "The justice understood constitutional equality was an ongoing project, and she spent her life expanding equal citizenship to all Americans." https://t.co/sUYsBnCOjT

name: Slate
text: Her legacy is at stake. https://t.co/flB6Y67xGB
